title: What are the cheapest online shopping sites? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let’s be honest, grocery shopping can be expensive, especially when you go in only needing a few essentials like milk and bread, then come out with a cart-full of foods you didn’t even know you were craving (we’re looking at you, Cheese-Itz). While many stores have sales, there are other ways to sneak in some great and surprising deals that stores don’t want you knowing about. What I’ve been doing for the last couple of years is called simple price watching. Many websites now give you the option to track down the best price on the majority of groceries and if you’re a regular shopper who plans their shopping list, it’s easy to track down items that you really need. Here are some of the services that I’ve tried in the last couple of years: ● https://www.kupino.com ● https://www.groupon.com ● https://www.tiendeo.us ● https://slickdeals.net There are also other ways to sneak in some deals, which don’t necessarily include price-watching technique and these are: Couponing: You can pretty much find coupons anywhere if you try hard enough. First, there are flyers. A lot of stores and even local newspapers and magazines store coupons in their pages. There are also many online sites that are solely for finding coupons. Apps like Weekly Ads and Hot Deals from 120,671 Stores | Kupino.com or Groupon® Official Site | Online Shopping Deals and Coupons | Save Up to 70% off hundreds of deals and offers, dissecting them by store or product for quick and easy finds.Meat Portioning Technique: Don’t be shy, when you’re getting meat from the Deli section, ask the butcher for the whole thing. For example, buy a roast, have the butcher remove the bone (and use it for soup), run half of the roast through the grinder for chopped meat, and then take the leftover for a pot roast. That portion control saves about 30%, compared to buying sliced meat.Price-per-unit comparison: Check out the pricing labels on the shelves. Compare unit prices and sales prices. This is the cost of the item per unit. If the slightly-higher-priced item has a smaller unit price, you’ve got a bargain.Cashback: If you’re going to spend, you might as well make some of that money back. Cashback reward programs are sometimes offered from credit card companies, and a percentage of the amount spent is paid back to the card holder.Source: Buzzfeed
